entries.title: Color Code
template: ColorCode is a web app intended to help independent software developers choose color palettes for their UI. ColorCode development began in September 2021 and was completed with two partners by December 2021. My primary responsibility is UI design and front-end development.
To pitch this idea, my team developed a persona and rough draft wireframe for both mobile and desktop.
Following user feedback on our thumbnails, we found that many users felt intimidated by the number of features provided and terminology they didn't recognize.
To fix this, I iterated on the UI thumbnails to make it more approachable for users without color theory experience.

In order to develop our MVP1 within 2 weeks, we discovered we needed to tighten the scope of our app. Based on user feedback from our thumbnails, we decided to focus on the generation rather than the alteration of palettes.
We implemented our MVP1 using Python, Django and React.js.
With our MVP1 complete, we ran user testing and interviews with five users that matched our persona in order to determine our priorities for MVP2.

We were surprised by how positive user reactions were to our app, and we also gained helpful insight on what needed improving. Most urgently, users were dissatisfied with the color selection process, citing the difficulty of identifying which color they had chosen and the lack of custom hex code input.
Based on this research, we developed a list of improvements for MVP2.

In order to allow for custom color inputs, we redesigned our app to calculate the color in the JavaScript front-end and implemented custom color picking. We also improved the back-end generator and gave the UI a major overhaul so that the buttons better convey their behaviours and the app has a more consistent and accessible display.
Here is a demo of our finished MVP2:
entries.alt: Documentation for the web page Color Code
entries.caption: Palette Generator for Web Development

entries.title: 2D Studio Typography Stamp
entries.alt: A black question mark shaped stamp repeated, rotated and mirrored on white paper. The pattern of the marks makes a chain like pattern.

entries.title: 2D Studio Compositions
entries.alt: A three by three grid of nine black and white compositions. All demonstrate sinuous, flowing edges and sharp corners.
entries.caption: Explorations into shape and negative space. Permanent marker on paper.

entries.title: 2D Studio Digital Typography
entries.alt: A set of six black and white compositions, all using typography of the letters D and M in various scales and fonts.
entries.caption: Experiments in composition and typography using my own initials.

entries.title: 2D Studio Papercraft
entries.alt: Two versions of the same abstract splashy composition, rotated 180 degrees. One is in reds and pinks, while the other is in blues and greens.
entries.caption: Papercut exploration into color and direction

entries.title: Ligature 1
entries.alt: A ligature in a bold, curved font. The middle leg of the M becomes the tail of the J, and the D curves through the center.
entries.caption: One of five ligatures made with the initials DJM

entries.title: Ligature 2
entries.alt: A ligature in a blocky, scifi font. The right edge of the D becomes the first leg of the M, and the middle leg of the M becomes the tail of the J.
entries.caption: One of five ligatures made with the initials DJM

entries.title: Ligature 3
entries.alt: A ligature in a bold serif font. The D and M are separated by the negative space carving out a J between them.
entries.caption: One of five ligatures made with the initials DJM

entries.title: Ligature 4
entries.alt: A ligature in an angular blackletter font. The D and J link together to make the base for the M
entries.caption: One of five ligatures made with the initials DJM

entries.title: Perfect Page 1
entries.alt: A comic page showing a young teen reading on their laptop late at night. Text reads, "When I was younger, I read a lot of romance stories."
entries.caption: A comic about romance tropes, hopes, and experiences.

entries.title: Perfect Page 2
entries.alt: Panels of kisses and hands, overlaid with electricity. "In some of he stories, the first kiss was electric, and the emotions felt like fire, and it was perfect. I knew life wasn't like that, of course, but it was a nice thought. I have felt electricity, I have felt fire. They reach deep into your bones and tug on the deepest parts of your nerves. They leave you bursting and heated. It would be nice."
entries.caption: A comic about romance tropes, hopes, and experiences.

entries.title: Perfect Page 3
entries.alt: Panels showing nervous sweaty kisses, the boy carried by the wind and falling into a bed of leaves. "In some of the stories, the first kisses were awkward. Noses poked and elbows got in the way and it was described as "fumbling" and "messy" and "nervous". But they felt so strongly for each other that it was perfect anyways. This seemed closer to reality. The kind of built up suspense that heightens everything to perfection, like the first time you manage to pull the wind around you and lift yourself into the air (even if you do fall down all three inches and land on your ass)."
entries.caption: A comic about romance tropes, hopes, and experiences.

entries.title: Perfect Page 4
entries.alt: Panels show a blushing face, holding hands. "In some of the stories, it wasn't perfect. But it was still what they had been reaching, longing, hoping for, and with a little time and work and experimentation it would become perfect. So I was expecting the first kisses to be awkward, for our noses to smush uncomfortably; for our hands to slip and fumble against each other's faces, for our elbows to accidentally find each other's sides. What I didn't expect was to feel", a panel of the boy, older, blank faced, "nothing at all."
entries.caption: A comic about romance tropes, hopes, and experiences.

entries.title: Perfect Page 5
entries.alt: "The kisses were not electric, but I knew we would learn. I learned how to tilt my head. I learned how to use my mouth." Panels of the boy kissing his partner, emotionless. "Nothing changed. The kisses remained exactly what they were: aforeign slide of soft skin against my own. Not particularly interesting." A panel of the boy hugging his partner, looking solemn. His partner watches him, concerned and flushed. "Not particularly perfect. (I like hugs better.)"
entries.caption: A comic about romance tropes, hopes, and experiences.

entries.title: Perfect Page 6
entries.alt: A panel of the boy reaching out again. "I enjoy making the people I care about feel good." A panel of the boy once again reading on his laptop. "I just wish it worked for me." A panel of the mouse hovering over the close button.
entries.caption: A comic about romance tropes, hopes, and experiences.

entries.title: Damien Tiamat Character Sheet
entries.alt: Portrait turnaround and fullbody outfits for a young man with large fin ears and floppy hair. Outfits include a waistcoat and slacks over a buttonup shirt and a loosely draped toga.
entries.caption: Comic concept character designs

entries.title: Sterling Character Design
entries.alt: Three line drawings of the same character with a sharp face and rough bowlcut. The first outfit is a fitted tunic with a thick belt and embroidery. The second outfit is a loose tunic with one arm in a sling. The third outfit is an intricate robe and stola with heavy beaded fringes and headpiece.
entries.caption: Comic concept character designs for a fantasy comic set in Byzantine Constantinople

entries.title: The Captain Character Design
entries.alt: Two headshots of a woman, one in profile and one head on. She has a strong jaw, a broad smile with sharp teeth, and heavy brows. Her long hair is pulled back into several braids and she is wearing a cloak with an asymmetrical fur collar.
entries.caption: Comic concept character designs for a fantasy comic set in Byzantine Constantinople

entries.title: Naimbir Ch1 Character Designs
entries.alt: A character lineup in shades of gold. From left to right: a tired looking person with a fitted tunic and a thick belt and many pieces of jewelry; a small lizard like monster; the same tired person, this time without jewelry and in a dirty shift with one arm in a sling; a rabbit-like creature, and a tall woman with a wolf skull for a head in full robes and a large scarf
entries.caption: Comic concept character designs for the first chapter of a fantasy comic set in Byzantine Constantinople
